column4: Hi, NFS entries in /etc/fstab are only mounted automatically on first login. How can I automount them also when switching user?
i would think if the fstab entry was correct. it wouldmount at Boot time. Not login.
Yes, you are right. But that makes the entries only work on first login, not when I switch user
mine work at boot time.. befor anyone even logs in..
double check your fstab entries perhaps for starters
Ok, this is my fstab: http://pastebin.com/QYAbkW2T Do you see anything wrong with it?
well the only option you have is auto,users... so Im guessign the 'users' option is what you are not needing..
This setup does no mount when switching user, if I do sudo mount -a it mounts just fine but won't automount
that would seem to be allowing users to mount/unmount the nfs share.. is that even needed?
I thought so but I'll try without
EXACTLY what the users option is supposed to do...
Let users mount the nfs share, otherwise root is needed
at boot time . it would be mounted anyway
Ok, might be dependant on how the NFS is shared, but I'll try without 'users'
read up at -> https://help.ubuntu.com/community/SettingUpNFSHowTo
Thanks, I've read that page. Tried now with no 'users' option but still same problem. First time I login Fileserver is mounted but if I log out and then back in it's not mounted anymore
that autofs tool mounts them on first access. perhaps that would suite your needs.
i just set mine up in fstab and have a /media/NFS/othermachines   mountpoint i used to use.
Well that is yet another daemon running but sure, I'll give it a try.
i have never had users unmonting nfs shares. so you may want to double check that guide.
you can even set up /home/ to be a nfs share.  so users having controll is defainatly not needed :)
